column8: ,4 month work term,The Ecology lab is the central teaching facility and resource centre available to all ENV students. ENV students will use the facility throughout their academic career for environmental related courses and research. Field ecology, hydroclimatology, restoration ecology, and geomorphology are just a few courses that use the lab. A variety of theses research and course projects are conducted in the lab ranging from water quality and soil nutrient testing to plant and invertebrate identification and experimentation. The facility houses a reference library, herbarium, archive of project reports and both field and laboratory equipment for use in projects, theses and course work.

column1: http://uwaterloo.ca/ecology-lab","Conduct water and soil nutrient analysis.
Assist students in identifying plants, invertebrate and other fauna.
Conduct field and laboratory demonstrations of equipment and sampling protocols.
Lead in social media calendar & postings
Assist with planning and conducting outreach programs.
Support ENV courses requiring virtual and in-person field and lab services.
Create & edit online videos related to online course lab delivery
Regular data retrieval of campus creek data.
Regular data collection in UW urban forest.
Other duties as assigned.","Completed Field Ecology (ENVS 200).
Physical Geography, field techniques type courses an asset.
Knowledge of Ontario nature (flora, fauna, geology) and understanding of ecological concepts.
Energetic, enthusiastic, and self-starter.
Excellent oral communication and technical writing communication.
Must be able to handle multiple tasks and balance work load in busy lab environment with competing multiple demands.
Must be able to work outdoors in various weather conditions and bugs (humid, rainy, buggy).
Must be able to work with chemicals and abide by safety protocols.
Interpersonal, conceptual, and organizational skills.
Demonstrated ability to work independently and as a team, follow and carry out instructions.
Ability to work outdoors, conduct field research and in-lab analysis.
Assist lab users in identifying flora and fauna and willingness to learn new skills.
Willingness to help students with experiments and analysis.
Technical knowledge of video editing & social media delivery.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Faculty of Environment is committed to attracting the best and the brightest students to help shape a sustainable future. To do this, the Marketing and Recruitment team creates and implements initiatives to help increase undergraduate enrollment. As the Recruitment and Marketing Associate, you'll be helping to plan and execute recruitment activities like Open Houses, overseeing our Student Ambassador Team, contributing to our social media presence, and interacting with future Environment students. We are looking for a personable, organized, and creative individual to help us work towards these goals in a fast-paced, people-first environment.

column1: NOTE: The successful candidate must have received OSAP funding in the term immediately before the work term to be eligible for this position.

Please be mindful that in the uncertainty of COVID-19 this role's responsibilities will be more focused on digital marketing and virtual recruitment efforts with the potential for increased on-campus activities as public health allows in Winter 2022.","A typical day (if there is one) may look like:
Start out by checking the CRM to see if anyone has booked a tour, then meet our guests in the Visitors Centre and show them around our Environment buildings
Edit a video profiling one of our students who just completed a really cool co-op job
Respond to an email from an International student looking into admission requirements
Make recommendations on where we should target recruitment activities by analyzing prospective student data gathered from a survey you conducted
Attend a Recruitment Roundtable meeting and share ideas on what our Open House sessions will offer
Make edits to our webpages and program flyers in preparation for our next event
Brainstorm a compelling Instagram story you can create and post to engage with prospective students
Chat with one of our vendors and discuss some possible swag items to use as giveaways promoting the faculty","This might be right for you if:
You're enrolled in a Faculty of Environment program.
You're an enthusiastic member of a team, able to take charge and stand in the spotlight, but also just as happy to ensure everything is running smoothly behind the scenes.
You're a natural when it comes to helping people, and make it standard to go above and beyond in your interactions with others
You're self-motivated and take initiative to start new projects without being asked
You think creatively and outside of the box, but also know how to pay attention to details and stay focused on your priorities
Your communication skills are top-notch
You are comfortable speaking to groups of people, and proud to have your writing displayed online
You might also stand out if you have:
Knowledge and passion for the Faculty of Environment's mission and values
Experience in recruitment, marketing, sales, event planning, writing, publishing, and/or public speaking
Creative skills in fine arts, digital media, photography/video making, and know how to use Adobe Creative Suite
A strong desire to learn and grow, ask questions, and bring your best each day.
Interested?

We're excited to add your energy and ideas to our team. If you feel you have only some of the qualifications we're looking for, but you're willing to work hard and learn the rest, we'd still love to see your application!","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The MAD workshop (https://uwaterloo.ca/environment-computing/facilities/mad-workshop) is the fabrication and design makerspace available to all ENV students. The workshop combines a traditional workshop with emergent digital technologies, such as a Laser Cutter, a 3D printer, and 3D scanner. ENV students use the facility throughout their academic career for environmental related courses and research. For this Winter term an emphasis will be on the Knowledge Integration students who will be working on their ""museum exhibits"" for the annual Knowledge Integration Exhibition (KIX) https://uwaterloo.ca/knowledge-integration-exhibition/. This is an exciting time in the workshop and the successful applicant will be exposed to a wide range of activities.","Assist students in the design and construction of projects created within the workshop.

column1: Assist students in the creation or preparation of files for laser cutting and 3D printing.
Operating the laser cutter and 3d printer and instructing/supervising the students' usage of these devices.
Working with the Workshop Coordinator on assorted projects.
Writing and updating SOPs (Standard Operating Procedures) for equipment and processes within the workshop, and updating website pages.
Assist in the support of ""virtual exhibits"" that will also be part of KIX.
Assist in the daily maintenance of the workshop
Other duties as assigned.","• Knowledge in 2D/3D design software (eg Sketchup, Autocad, Inventor)
• Experience or interest in VR technologies

column8: ,8 month consecutive work term preferred,The Sustainability Projects Coordinator is a core member of the University of Waterloo's Sustainability team, assisting in all areas of campus sustainability. This role presents an excellent opportunity for students to network with a wide variety of stakeholders, gain experience planning institutional sustainability initiatives and projects, as well as develop effective and creative strategies for implementation.

column1: It is expected that there will be two positions available, which will divide and collaborate on projects based on student strengths and interests. Both roles will have opportunity for collaboration to gain a well-rounded experience and specific projects will be mutually agreed upon at the start of the term.
Please note, preference will be given for an 8-month term (Winter and Spring terms 2022).

The position will report to the University of Waterloo's Director of Sustainability.","Typical working hours are 8:30 AM -4:30 PM, with occasional evening or weekend work for events and engagement activities. Given COVID-19 measures, it is expected that this position will be have a mix of some on-site and remote work.
This position will support all functions of the Sustainability Office through project-based work and program implementation. Responsibilities will include, but are not limited to:
Outreach and Communications Support:
Supporting development and delivery of the Green Residence Ambassador program
Providing logistical support for the employee Sustainability Certificate training program
Development and implementation of events and activities for Earth Month
Supporting communication and engagement initiatives, including developing and distributing content for Social Media platforms, email, poster, and web channels
Leading the Sustainability Office Podcast and Blog development
Research, Data, and Project Support:
Supporting development and delivery of the Green Labs program
Supporting development and delivery of the Green Office program
Conducting research on peer best practice, case studies, and benchmarking for background to advance campus sustainability efforts
Assisting in development of project plans and business plans for sustainability initiatives that align with the Environmental Sustainability Strategy
Collecting and analyzing data related to sustainability as part of the University's ongoing reporting requirements
Other responsibilities:

Liaising with other campus departments (for example Plant Operations, Food Services, Housing, etc.) on program development and delivery for initiatives supporting the Environmental Sustainability strategy.

Supporting administrative processes of the Sustainability Office, including but not limited to taking meeting minutes and booking rooms, coordinating printing, updating the sustainability website, and tracking office assets

Given the uncertain nature of COVID-19, it is expected that the specific project list will be fluid throughout the term as the University responds to changing circumstances.","A successful candidate should bring:
Strong organizational skills and an ability to prioritize and multi-task
Keen attention to detail
Demonstrated creative thinking
Excellent written and verbal communication skills
High degree of proficiency in Microsoft Word, Excel, and Outlook
Strong ability to qualitatively and quantitatively analyze information and data
Understanding of project design and management principles
Demonstrated knowledge of campus, institutional, or business sustainability issues and frameworks, including the UN Sustainable Development Goals, STARS, and the GRI
Outreach and Communications:
Experience with professional social media platforms
Experience in design of marketing materials and other communication assets
Experience with Podcasts, blogs, and other online platforms
Strong experience with data analysis (databases, pivot tables, statistics)
Experience conducting research and developing policy recommendations on sustainability-related topics","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The University of Waterloo and York University are collaborating on the Intelligent Systems for Sustainable Urban Mobility (ISSUM) project to develop new technologies that will improve urban mobility and accessibility for a range of transportation modes (i.e. freight and passenger vehicles, transit, cycling and walking).  We are seeking a seeking a software developer/engineering for a 4 month co-op position to assist with the development, testing and refinement of an augmented/virtual reality platform that will assist transportation planners with the design of transit station areas.","The successful candidate will work with the lead investigator and a team of research assistants at the University of Waterloo and York University on the design and development of an augmented reality platform that will support interactive visualization and design of urban transportation scenarios.  The successful candidate will work closely with the project team to:

column1: Design and evaluate the augmented reality environment,
Acquire, process and manage 3D model data,
Perform functional testing and resolve product issues,

Demonstrate the prototype to university and government project partners.","The ideal candidate will have demonstrated skills and experience in the development of cloud-based applications that link databases, application logic and user interfaces to deliver our applications across mobile platforms.  Skills required include:
Strong proficiency with C#, Python and/or Javascript,
Experience using APIs,
Integration of data storage solutions,
Strong documentation and communication skills.
In addition, candidates who have experience working with Unity 3D or geospatial software such as ArcGIS Pro is ideal but not required.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Centre for Community, Clinical and Applied Research Excellence (CCCARE) is seeking a Research and Operations Administrative Assistant. The Research and Operations Administrative Assistant will provide support for the operation of CCCARE research and program initiatives, under the direction of the CCCARE Research and Operations Manager. This position will assist with administrative details, coordination of logistics and other duties as required to support the successful delivery of CCCARE research studies and clinical exercise programming. The Research and Operations Administrative Assistant will serve as a resource to ensure that CCCARE research studies are being conducted in accordance with University standards. This position will be part of the Department of Kinesiology and Health Sciences and thus will be required to operate within a team environment, providing proactive support to others and upholding the department's standards for professionalism.","Responsibilities of the research and operations assistant include:

column1: Administrative responsibilities include answering phone calls, emails, questions, scheduling using Fusion software and handling correspondences in a timely and professional manner
Must engage with CCCARE program and research participants, both in person at the front reception desk and through maintaining CCCARE's online presence (e.g., Newsletter, Social Media, etc.)
Assist Research and Operations Manager in tracking and organization of research activities, coordinating volunteer activities, and community events
Work collaboratively with CCCARE Staff on initiatives related to clinical exercise and nutrition programming
Assist graduate students in ongoing data collection, analysis, and database management in various Kinesiology related research studies
Complete all research and safety training modules and assist in monthly lab safety inspections
Keep the reception area clean and organized, ensure front desk is well attended at all times, ensure cleanliness of gym facility, unlock and lock gym facility during regular business hours

Report any issues with equipment or facilities directly to the Research and Operations Manager","Excellent interpersonal skills to present as a friendly, professional advocate for the department and its activities and to foster good working relationships with a variety of clients including students, staff and faculty
Ability to demonstrate competence in Kinesiology research assessment and evaluation tools and techniques
Research experience working with clinical studies, exposure to laboratory environments and database management skills considered an asset

Familiarity and expertise with social media platforms and online communication tools (such as Mailchimp, Twitter and Facebook) and/or experience with Innosoft Fusion software considered a strong asset
Previous volunteer experience with CCCARE programs considered an asset (e.g. UW WELL-FIT, STEPS, Brain & Body, Teens In Motion, etc.)
Valid first aid","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Geriatric Health Systems Research Group (https://uwaterloo.ca/geriatric-health-systems-research-group/) is a research team, under the direction of Dr. Paul Stolee, located within the School of Public Health and Health Systems, and is involved in research broadly aimed at improving systems of health care for older persons. Current research involves enhancing rehabilitation services for older persons through enhanced use and sharing of health information ? research methods include advanced statistical analyses, qualitative methods, and consultation with stakeholders.

column1: The research assistant will work directly with Dr. Paul Stolee, Professor; Sheila Bodemer, Research Coordinator, as well as with the larger GHS team which includes faculty investigators, graduate students completing research projects, and collaborators from across Canada.","Provide research assistance and support to various projects related to studies of aging and health services for older people.
Search and summarize relevant literature.
Review transcriptions for accuracy
Assist in developing approaches (e.g., developing a data base) for analyses of the data collected.
Work with the faculty research investigators and students in preparing manuscripts for publication.
Assist other members of the research team and engage in other duties as necessary.

column8: ,4 month work term,The Institutional Research (IR) team within the Office of Research has a 4-month co-op position for the Winter 2022 term to assist with grant submission and contract processes. The IR team is responsible for reviewing research proposals, budgets and contractual terms to ensure compliance as part of the funding procurement process. The IR team organizes and conducts workshops for faculty to support effective grant writing and as a means to facilitate collaboration among researchers and research groups. The IR group is also responsible for the compilation and provision of statistics and reports related to grant applications and awards. The IR team informs and advises the University of Waterloo research community about granting agency policies and guidelines pertaining to research grants, and ensures compliance with these policies as well as with the Tri-agency Agreement (Tri-agencies are SSHRC, CIHR, and NSERC).

column1: Skills Gained:
Marketable administrative experience skills (e.g., welcoming guests).
Strong time-management, organizational, and communication skills as well as experience with data entry and database management.
Valuable information about government grants submission processes.
Skills organizing and running successful workshops.
Practical experience conducting descriptive statistics.

Valuable skills working independently and as part of a team.","The co-op student will assist team members with the execution of submitting grants from organizing intake of drafts to review of proposals, to submission to funding agencies. For example, the student will be responsible for:
Collecting authorized internal approval forms
Providing administrative management of individual grants throughout the application process (e.g., creating folders, organizing submissions as they arrive)
Performing initial scan of grant submissions for completeness of required sections, and formatting requirements
Assisting with reviewing parts or certain sections of grant applications
Completing grant checklists to ensure completeness of applications
Requesting and keeping track of letters of reference, as required
Communicating with faculty about outstanding items and/or reviewed grants
Entering application information into research administrative database
Following-up and communicating with researchers, both internal and external, to the University
Performing front desk reception and assisting with office operations
Assisting with compiling statistics, as required
Assisting with mail outs, as required
Completing special projects, as assigned.","The incumbent will be highly detail-oriented with excellent communication (oral and written), organizational and time management skills.
The ability to learn quickly, exercise strong problem-solving skills and work independently in a fast-paced environment is also necessary.
The incumbent will also have strong computer skills, especially experience with the Microsoft Office Suite.
Familiarity with the grant submission process would be an asset.
Experience with office administration is an asset.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,You are passionate about experiential learning. You are a strong advocate for the Kinesiology and Health Sciences program and the University of Waterloo. You want to positively impact the university experience of your peers and believe strongly in community and engagement. You are creative, open-minded, and view challenges as opportunities or learning experiences.","The incumbent will assist with a variety of tasks including:

column1: - Assist with preparation and in-person and/or virtual delivery of core undergraduate Kinesiology courses including but not limited to KIN 204L and 221L.

column8: ,4 month work term,General Responsibilities

column1: ·       Schedule and assist in remote data collections for ONDRI@Home (see below)
·       Keep records of equipment location and status; maintain equipment inventory and order additional equipment/supplies as needed
·       Identify and evaluate emerging technologies in the remote health-monitoring field
·       Support team's knowledge translation and publication efforts with writing, literature reviews, and data processing
·       Assist with the analysis of large wearable sensor data repositories collected within ONDRI@Home project(s)
About ONDRI@Home

·       The ONDRI (Ontario Neurodegenerative Disease Research Initiative) @Home project began in the Fall of 2018. This project aims to monitor health behaviours outside of the clinic in the home and community using wearable biosensors and supporting technology. Its goal is to identify measures capable of capturing declining health, which may lead to earlier diagnoses, and to monitor disease progression and treatment efficacy for persons living with neurodegenerative disease. A unique challenge of the @Home project is the need to manage both large volumes of data captured from multiple wearable sensors, and the coordination and transportation of these sensors during remote data collections.

·       To date, the @Home project has conducted three primary studies to determine the most appropriate wearable technology for continuous, multi-day data collection, and how to extract meaningful outcome measures from this large volume of raw data. Ongoing work is being conducted to develop new analytical techniques in addition to improving existing methods.

·       This role will be in support of the HANDDS-ONT (Health in Aging and Neurodegenerative Diseases and DementiaS in Ontario) project, which began data collections across Ontario in September 2021. This study aims to compare different fluid biomarkers, clinical data, and behavioural data obtained using wearables technologies at home in interconnected studies conducted in healthy older adults and people living with cerebrovascular disease, dementia, Parkinson's disease, and ALS.","·       Head the remote @Home data collections throughout the term

·      Responsibilities include preparing study materials, scheduling, and supporting data collections with participants, organizing equipment transportation, managing, and organizing incoming data, maintaining logs of data collection details or protocols, and supporting ordering and testing of additional equipment
·       Design and develop ONDRI@Home knowledge translation materials and support knowledge translation activities

·       Prepare communications related to study progress for various ONDRI groups which may include the HANDDS-ONT working group or the Patient and Community Advisory Committee or at an external conference
·       Identify a gap or opportunity to advance ONDRI@Home projects based on a specific area of interest and develop a plan to address it, time permitting
·       Lead routine testing of new wearable technologies and share information with the lab regarding existing or emerging remote health monitoring products, platforms, and trends

·       Assist with other ONDRI@Home research activities as necessary","·       Ability to engage and share information with older adult participants and those living with neurodegenerative disease or dementia and their care partner(s)
·       Critical thinking to review outputs from the wearables data for personalized patient reports about health-related behaviours including activity, mobility, sleep, social engagement, etc.
·       Strong organization skills to manage and keep track of the incoming/outgoing equipment needed for data collections and the collected data
·       Excellent communication skills to engage with various stakeholders including researchers, clinicians, and participants
·       Ability to work both independently and collaboratively with a multi-disciplinary team to solve problems as they arise
·       Proficiency in Microsoft Office
·       First aid/CPR certification is a benefit but not necessary","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,This is a joint position with the Neuroscience, Mobility, & Balance (NiMBaL) Kinesiology lab and the Neural Rehabilitation Engineering (NRE) lab in Mechanical and Mechatronics Engineering.

column1: Job Summary

We are seeking a student who is eager to apply their expertise in math, programming, advanced analytics techniques, and data science to improve healthcare. The student will focus on development of novel analytical approaches to maximize utility of outcomes for key health indicators (e.g. activity, sleep, social engagement) derived from wearable sensor data.
The NiMBaL and NRE research teams focus on:
-Understanding how the brain and other parts of the central nervous system control human movement
-Applying concepts of remote patient monitoring and big data techniques to self- and clinical management of health and disease
-Advancing assistive technology for independent mobility and rehabilitation by applying principles of biomedical signal processing, data science, and robotics.

-Translating this knowledge for early detection and prevention of health decline, monitoring disease progression and treatment effectiveness, and helping individuals to maximize their recovery following a neurological injury, such as a stroke.

We interpret this information to help find ways to minimize age- and disease-related effects on health and movement control. We conduct research in university-based and hospital-based labs and in the community using portable, cost-effective measurement tools.
Ontario Neurodegenerative Disease Research Initiative (ONDRI)

The NiMBaL Lab conducts several research projects in collaboration with ONDRI (http://ondri.ca). ONDRI's objective is to improve the diagnosis and treatment of neurodegenerative diseases and dementias. ONDRI's first large-scale study was a longitudinal cohort study capturing data from hundreds of patients across multiple assessment domains including: gait and balance, neuroimaging, neuropsychology, clinical, eye-tracking, genetics, and spectral domain optical coherence tomography.

Most recently, ONDRI has launched a province-wide Master Observational Trial (HANDDS-ONT); an innovative, fully remote study including continuous monitoring of health-related behaviours (e.g. posture, activity, sleep, mobility, social engagement, and cognition). The NiMBaL lab co-leads the collection and analysis of ONDRI gait and balance data as well as data captured from wearable technologies worn at home and in the community. A unique challenge of the remote monitoring studies is the need to manage large volumes of data, captured from multiple sensors, measuring many behaviors over several days.

Since 2019, the NRE Lab has partnered with NiMBal to combine expertise in biophysical signal processing and applied research methods for application to aging and neurodegenerative disease (both within and beyond the ONDRI program of research). This partnership, which brings together engineers and computer scientists with applied health scientists and clinicians, affords a unique opportunity to advance tools and methods for health assessment outside of a clinic setting in real-world conditions.","Responsibilities
-Apply signal processing skills to biophysical signals to extract meaningful outcome measures
-Work with the NiMBaL and NRE teams to determine programming needs and objectives
-Critically review literature for existing algorithms/approaches and evaluate suitability for implementation with respect to team's research needs/objectives.

-Where gaps exist, develop, implement, and optimize new algorithms/approaches; ensure code is error-free, readable, efficient, and organized for subsequent users and ready for inclusion in our main data processing pipeline
-Design and develop protocols to validate new analytics
-Support publication efforts with writing, literature reviews, and data processing when necessary
-Apply signal processing skills to biophysical signals to extract meaningful outcome measures
-Work with the NiMBaL and NRE teams to determine programming needs and objectives
-Critically review literature for existing algorithms/approaches and evaluate suitability for implementation with respect to team's research needs/objectives.

-Where gaps exist, develop, implement, and optimize new algorithms/approaches; ensure code is error-free, readable, efficient, and organized for subsequent users and ready for inclusion in our main data processing pipeline
-Design and develop protocols to validate new analytics
-Support publication efforts with writing, literature reviews, and data processing when necessary
Project Opportunities

The program of research is focused on the application of wearable technology and other remote patient monitoring approaches to the advancement of health outcomes in older adults and persons living with neurodegenerative disease or dementia. Opportunities may include but are not limited to the following:

-Development and implementation of advanced analytics used to evaluate biophysical signals captured from wearable technology, including methods to detect onset and severity of disease symptoms in free-living conditions
-Building multi-modal and sensor fusion solutions for health behaviour monitoring

-Contributing to the codebase and development of open-source software packages","-Advanced quantitative and computer skills, including ability to use Python for data management and computational methods for data analysis
-Strong analytical, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills
-Knowledge of biomedical and applied research design and statistical methods
-Ability to communicate in a clear, concise manner, both written and verbal
-Detail oriented and process focused
-Ability to work independently in a self-directed manner as well as part of a team","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,8 month consecutive work term preferred,The Social Media Assistant is one of three co-op positions that works in collaboration with the Faculty of Health Dean's Office and a specific academic unit within the Faculty of Health (Recreation and Leisure Studies, School of Public Health Sciences, or Kinesiology and Health Sciences) to write, design, schedule, monitor and evaluate a variety of content for social media accounts. column8: ,4 month work term,Microbiology labwork: assistance is needed with on-going projects involving characterization and manipulation of intracellular genetic networks and intercellular interactions among bacterial populations. The work involves standard microbiology lab techniques (aseptic technique, inoculations, growth curves, transformations) along with some molecular biology (cloning) and quantitative characterization via flow cytometry and fluorescence microscopy.

column1: CS 106 is the follow-up course for CS105.  It is open to all students across campus (except CS/Math majors, who take CS 115, 135, 137, or 145), regardless of prior experience.

It uses the programming language Processing (based in Java), providing further exposure to functional programming, an introduction to imperative programming, and basic coverage of important issues in computer science.","Potential ISAs must have successfully completed two university-level Computer Science courses, and either know or be willing to rapidly master Processing.
The Macintosh platform is used in labs; experience with Macs, though beneficial, is not required.
Exposure to scripting is also an asset.

column8: ,4 month work term,The University of Waterloo, Faculty of Mathematics is looking for an outgoing student with strong technical and interpersonal skills to assist with special digital alumni engagement projects on behalf the Faculty. This position will be key to enabling the Advancement team to better connect and engage with alumni both locally and internationally, in a virtual setting. Some of the activities you will be responsible for are:

column1: Helping research alumni for the Faculty of Mathematics,
Supporting the organization and execution of online events,
Creating promotional materials (e.g videos, digital content) and enhance our web pages, and
Developing marketing and social media plans.
If you are creative and outgoing and want to make a difference in the Math Faculty, then this job is for you. The successful candidate will report to the Advancement Coordinator.","Responsibilities
Research alumni utilizing various databases, search engines, and spreadsheets to assist team in creating briefing notes for face-to-face meetings,
Ensure proper tracking and reporting of alumni engagement activities,
Assist in the development and maintenance of our various electronic recruitment and outreach initiatives,
Helping to engage and support alumni using the new Waterloo Math Digital Community platform, our primary engagement channel, focussing on digital engagement of Alumni
Develop fundraising-project specific pages on Math external site,
Waterloo Content Management System (WCMS) web page editing and migration
Develop the layout and design of promotional materials for virtual events,
Interview alumni and/or students and write profiles about them,
Edit videos of Math Faculty people, places, activities, and events,
Connect with future and current students, faculty, staff, and alumni online,
Assist in the planning and execution of various alumni and sponsorship events (including, but not limited to: Our new Waterloo Women's Impact Network and our new Entrepreneurship program),
Proactively and intentionally using various digital methodologies to connect with our various audiences
One-stop service for fundraisers for drafting and executing gift agreements
Other administrative duties as assigned","Qualifications
Strong written, communication, and interpersonal skills
Strong customer-service skills and customer-centred mindset
Strong understanding of professionalism and respecting confidentiality
Effective time-management skills
Self-starter requiring minimal supervision
Strong attention to detail
Experience with Adobe Photoshop
Experience with desktop publishing and web-editing tools,
Waterloo Content Management System (WCMS) experience an asset
Experience planning and running events is an asset
Familiarity with business and marketing strategies is an asset
Enthusiasm for and pride in the University of Waterloo
Interest in writing is an asset
Willingness to work outside of normal office hours on occasion
Preference will be given to Math students","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,This role involves significant autonomy and self-direction in day-to-day work. While the team is focused on a few major and recurrent projects, new assignments come up regularly. The function of this role is not repetitive, and the successful candidate will therefore be highly adaptable and ready to contribute to all stages of projects. As a results-oriented team, we value openness, collaboration, and forthright communication. This is a great opportunity for candidates interested in a dynamic team environment and gaining skills and connections for career growth.

column1: The Marketing Coordinator will support the Communications team in the Faculty of Mathematics with several large projects to aid us in improving our website, resources and branding. column8: ,4 month work term,Reporting to the Information Systems (IS) Manager, this position provides support, in collaboration with the IS Developer and IS Specialist, for implementation, testing, integration, deployment and maintenance of CEMC information technology assets that are supporting CEMC strategic goals and outreach operations. The technical support includes the CEMC's custom built software systems for client management, Mathematics and Computer Science contest ordering, e-commerce, invoicing, results processing, marking reporting, educational resource repository and technical event logistics.

column1: The CEMC is Canada's largest and most recognized outreach organization for promoting and creating activities and materials in mathematics and computer science and is housed within the Faculty of Mathematics at the University of Waterloo.","Systems Design Support
Assists in the creation of reusable test suites and test plans such as the dedicated development server which is used for unit and system testing.
Contributes to the creation of technical documentation across multiple projects, which are maintained and stored in a departmental shared drive.
Technical Support
Assists Information Systems staff in providing technical support and training on in-house built systems for departmental faculty, staff and co-op students.
Supports the redesign of systems based on end-user requests.
Assists in communication between end-users and developers to improve documentation.
Provides training support for IS team members to small groups or one-on-one training to users and stakeholders.
Time Management and Organization
Prioritizes activities, with support from the IS Manager, based on deadlines and resource availability.
Schedules completion dates and milestones; reviews weekly/monthly progress reports with oversight from the IS Manager.
Works within the time constraints of other departments (Finance, Central Stores, etc.) when engaged with interdepartmental, cross-team projects.
Client Service
Aides to resolve customer complaints and makes recommendations to improve customer service.
Assists in establishing policies and procedures to minimize customer/user issues.
Supports Faculty/Staff with their IT equipment needs such as installing new equipment.
Liaises with faculty and University IT departments to support the CEMC's hardware and software issues.","Education
Currently working toward a university degree at the University of Waterloo in IT related program with relevant experience required.
Experience
Minimum 2 years' experience in IT related field.
Some experience with the full system cycle: systems analysis, design testing, documentation, training and maintenance.
Some experience with registration systems, web accessibility, e-commerce, OMR scanning systems, streaming server or email list server is an asset.
Group training assistance experience of small teams would be considered an asset.
Knowledge/Skills/Abilities
Working knowledge of several programming languages, DBMSs and/or Servers are an asset.
Some knowledge of Linux, Apache, MySQL and PHP (LAMP), HTML5, CSS3, SQL, JavaScript and/or AJAX.
Knowledge of Python, jQuery, LaTex, MathJax, Scantron, OMR, Barcode, Reporting (FPDF and FPDI) are nice-to-haves.
Proven business-appropriate oral and written communications skills.
Maintains confidentiality and demonstrates a sensitivity to diversity.
Ability to respond to customer needs in a timely, professional, helpful and courteous manner regardless of customer attitude.
Ability and willingness to be trained quickly on new procedures.","Targeted Clusters

column1: -Reply to DS Grad program email/phone inquiries and update FAQ.

-Update and improve the management of student records.
-Receive, review, follow-up and track annual progress reports, degree completion requests and co-op work reports.
-Create and update process documents for role.","-Excellent interpersonal and communication skills (oral and written).

-Ability to work independently or participate effectively as a team member in an office environment, which has multiple deadlines and priorities while maintaining confidentiality.
-In providing guidance to others, knowledge of Waterloo's graduate policies and procedures an asset.

column1: Instructional Support Assistants (ISAs) provide primary student contact, serving as consultants for course-related material through consulting hours. They also have an opportunity to gain teaching experience by helping deliver tutorial  sessions, if desired.  Other duties include assignment marking, providing feedback to instructors on the design and wording of assignments and exams;  assisting in exam proctoring and marking.","CS 136 is the followup course to CS 135.  It uses both the functional language Racket and the imperative language C in order to discuss real-world issues of expressivity, efficiency, modularity, and code re-use. While it is aimed at CS majors, many non-majors also take the course.

The ISA will help with development work relating to tutorials, marking schemes, automarking tests, and assistance in helping students make the transition from a graphical IDE to a Unix command-line environment. They will need to anticipate difficulties and move to minimize them, and to work relatively independently yet in accordance with the overall philosophy of the course as envisioned by the instructor.","Potential ISAs must have successfully completed three university-level Computer Science courses.
Experience with at least one of Racket and C would be helpful, preferably both.

Communication skills, critical thinking, and the ability to successfully interact with a wide range of people (undergraduates, graduate IAs and TAs, academic staff, professors) will be crucial.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Instructional Support Group (ISG) is seeking an enthusiastic and dependable person to assume an Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) role for an introductory computer science course for non-majors called CS 105. This course will use media computation to teach the fundamentals of programming.

column1: The teaching team consists of course instructors, graduate Instructional Apprentices, graduate Teaching Assistants, and Instructional Support Assistants (ISAs).","ISAs provide the primary student contact, serving as consultants for course-related material through consulting hours. They also have an opportunity to gain teaching experience by introducing and supervising lab sessions.  In addition, ISAs gain organizational experience by co-ordinating the activities of the graduate teaching assistants assigned to the course. Other duties include creation of marking schemes and automarking tests, providing feedback to instructors on the design and wording of labs, assignments, and exams, and assisting in proctoring and marking.

This course uses JavaScript language, in OpenProcessing.org. The course teaches programming fundamentals like variables, loops, and branching using code to create graphical output and dynamic interactive programs. CS 105 will be open to Global Business and Digital Arts and all non-math students regardless of prior experience.","The potential ISAs should have:

Successfully completed two university-level Computer Science courses, and either know or be willing to rapidly master the Processing language.  The Macintosh platform is used in labs; experience with Macs, though beneficial, is not required.
An interest in visual art and design is also an asset.

Successful candidates will have good communication and interpersonal skills, and the judgment and ability to work both independently and in collaboration with others, in accordance with the overall course goals and philosophy.
Student Leadership Certification or courses in Student Leadership through the Student Success Office an asset.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Instructional Support Group is seeking an enthusiastic and dependable person to assume a valuable role in the CS100 ONLINE teaching team. A teaching team consists of the course instructors,Instructional Support Assistants (ISAs), and graduate Teaching Assistants and Instructional Apprentices.","CS100 ISAs will provide the primary student contact related to modules and assignments, including guidance, feedback and marking. ISAs will also provide consulting hours in lab for students who have access to the UW main campus. Secondary duties might include monitoring the course discussion groups, maintaining the course web site, and assisting with the development of course materials.","To qualify for this position:

column1: You should have completed at least one university-level computing course (such as CS100, CS115, CS135, CS200).
Familiarity with a variety of software applications and web tools, especially spreadsheets, HTML, XML, search engines and wikis, is an asset as is some programming knowledge.
Our ideal teaching team consists of a mix of people with different strengths; technical superiority is not a requirement of this position, only a desire to learn and a desire to teach others.
Excellent communication, interpersonal and time management skills are critical to success in this position.
Previous leadership experience (such as teaching or coaching) is a definite asset.

Note that Fall 2009 was the first offering of a newly revised CS100 course: Introduction to Computing through Applications, focusing on effective use of spreadsheets; introduction to the Internet, World Wide Web, HTML, and XML; components of web search engines and their influence on data access; using wikis to publish, reshape, and organize data collaboratively","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Instructional Support Group (ISG) is seeking enthusiastic and dependable people to assume valuable roles in the CS 115 teaching team.

column1: The teaching team consists of course instructors, graduate Instructional Apprentices, graduate Teaching Assistants, and Instructional Support Assistants (ISAs).

ISAs provide the primary student contact, serving as consultants for course-related material through consulting hours. They also have an opportunity to gain teaching experience by introducing and supervising lab sessions.  In addition, ISAs gain organizational experience by co-ordinating the activities of the graduate teaching assistants assigned to the course. Other duties include creation of marking schemes and automarking tests, providing feedback to instructors on the design and wording of labs, assignments, and exams, and assisting in proctoring and marking.","CS 115 is open to all students across campus (except CS majors, who take CS 135 or CS 145), regardless of prior experience.  It uses the functional programming language Racket to introduce students to concepts of computer science, demonstrating links between computing and many other disciplines.","Potential ISAs should have successfully completed two university-level Computer Science courses, and either know or be willing to rapidly master Racket.
The Macintosh platform is used in labs; experience with Macs, though beneficial, is not required.
Exposure to scripting is also an asset.

Successful candidates will have good communication and interpersonal skills, and the judgement and ability to work both independently and in collaboration with others, in accordance with the overall course goals and philosophy.
Student Leadership Certification or courses in Student Leadership through the Student Success Office an asset.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Instructional Support Group requires an Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) to assist in the delivery of  CS240 as part of a team of instructors, graduate Instructional Apprentices (IAs), graduate Teaching Assistants (TAs) and an Instructional Support Coordinator (ISC).","The Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) provides the primary student contact, serving as a consultant for course-related material through consulting hours and on-line communication. ISAs also provide feedback to instructors on assignments and other course materials and contribute to a quality learning experience for students. There is an opportunity to gain teaching experience by giving tutorials. The ISA may also develop these tutorials. Experience will be gained as co-ordinator of the assignment marking activities of the TAs assigned to the course.  Other duties may include creation of model solutions and marking schemes and creation of scripts needed for assignment testing and auto-marking. The ISA also assists with proctoring and marking exams and performs various other tasks to ensure the smooth running of the course. Training, mentoring and other resources are provided and there is the opportunity for growth in many areas, technical, personal and interpersonal, depending on the individual.

column4: This position may be of particular interest to students who are considering graduate school and ultimately teaching at the post-secondary level.","Good communication, time  management and interpersonal skills, attention to detail and a proactive work attitude are required.

column8: ,4 month work term,The Instructional Support Group requires an Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) to assist in the delivery of  CS 240E as part of a team of instructors, graduate Instructional Apprentices (IAs), graduate Teaching Assistants (TAs) and an Instructional Support Coordinator (ISC).

column1: CS 240E is an enriched version of CS 240 offered in the Winter and Spring terms, if there is sufficient demand.

The intended audience is interested Computer Science students who have earned a grade of 85% or higher in CS 145, or 90% or higher in both CS 135 and CS 136.","The Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) provides the primary student contact, serving as a consultant for course-related material through consulting hours and on-line communication. ISAs also provide feedback to instructors on assignments and other course materials and contribute to a quality learning experience for students. There is an opportunity to gain teaching experience by giving tutorials. The ISA may also develop these tutorials. Experience will be gained as co-ordinator of the assignment marking activities of the TAs assigned to the course.  Other duties may include creation of model solutions and marking schemes, and creation of scripts needed for assignment testing and auto-marking. The ISA also assists with proctoring and marking exams, and performs various other tasks to ensure the smooth running of the course. Training, mentoring and other resources are provided and there is the opportunity for growth in many areas, technical, personal and interpersonal, depending on the individual.

This position may be of particular interest to students who are considering graduate school and ultimately teaching at the post-secondary level.","Good communication, time management and interpersonal skills, attention to detail and a proactive work attitude are required.
Familiarity with Linux and C++
Experience with a statically-typed functional programming language would be an asset.
Students currently enrolled in the course are encouraged to apply.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Instructional Support Group (ISG) is seeking an enthusiastic and dependable person to assume a valuable role of Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) in the CS 146 teaching team. The teaching team consists of the course instructor, the ISA and an Instructional Support Coordinator (ISC).","The Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) provides primary student contact, serving as a consultant for course-related material through consulting hours and other means of communication. The ISA may have an opportunity to gain teaching experience by helping to deliver tutorial sessions. Other duties include setting up auto-testing, hand-marking of written and style components of assignments, providing feedback to the instructor on the design and wording of assignments and exams, web page maintenance, creating and documenting re-usable scripts to make processes more efficient, helping come up with and implement better ways to engage students and assisting in exam proctoring (when classes are ""in person"") and marking. Since CS 146 is only offered once a year and has advanced students, its ISA will experience skill enhancing challenges and must demonstrate more individual initiative and responsibility (good for future resumés, interviews and jobs).

column1: CS 146 is an advanced-level version of CS 136, normally taken by students in their 1B term. It is aimed at top students in the Faculty of Mathematics, with admission based on either successful completion of CS 145 (itself requiring high scores in math and computing contests or instructor consent for admission), or by instructor consent based on exceptional performance in CS 135.
CS 146 has been offered since Winter 2012. CS 145 and CS 146 together bring the treatment of advanced first-year CS courses in line with advanced Math courses.

The ISA will have the chance to advise on and participate in further development work. Students considering graduate and academia work in Computer Science will find this job very useful and educational.","Potential ISAs must have good grades and  have experience with Racket  or Scheme or be willing to rapidly master this language before commencing work.
Experience with C is necessary.
Experience with the advanced Math and/or CS courses would be desirable.

Communication skills, critical thinking, and the ability to deal with the type of student who takes advanced courses will be crucial. The ISA will have to master several topics not typically covered in the CS undergraduate core (for example, garbage collection, and the CPS transform).

The successful candidate will also have strong interpersonal and time management abilities, attention to detail,  a proactive work attitude, good judgement and the ability to work independently and as part of a team within the spirit of course goals and philosophies.
Student Leadership Certification or courses in the Student Leadership program (Student Success Office) are an asset.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Instructional Support Group (ISG) is seeking an enthusiastic and dependable person to assume a valuable role of Instructional Support Assistant (ISA) in the CS 135 teaching team. The teaching team consists of course instructors, graduate Instructional Apprentices (IAs), graduate Teaching Assistants (TAs), ISAs and an Instructional Support Coordinator (ISC).","ISAs provide the primary student contact, supplying guidance for course-related material through consulting hours and on-line communication. ISAs also provide feedback (design, wording, difficulty, etc.) to instructors on assignments and other course materials. There is an opportunity to gain teaching and communication experience. In addition, ISAs gain organizational experience by co-ordinating the assignment marking activities of the graduate teaching assistants assigned to the course. Other duties include helping in the refinement of assignment marking schemes and creation of solution sets, hand-marking assignments, program auto-marking and correctness tests;  assisting in exam proctoring and marking; maintaining the course web page; and performing various other tasks to ensure the smooth operation of the course. Overall, they contribute to a quality learning experience for students. ISAs must also work cooperatively and closely with other CS 135 ISAs, as well as instructors for the course.

column1: This position may be of particular interest to students who are considering graduate school and/or ultimately teaching at the post-secondary level. It may also be of interest to students wanting to further their mastery of the material for future educational study and work.

CS 135 is the first course for CS majors but is open to all students. It uses the functional programming language Racket to introduce students to concepts of computer science.","Potential ISAs must have successfully completed at least two university-level Computer Science courses, and either know or be willing to rapidly master Racket.

The successful candidate will have good communication, interpersonal and time management abilities, attention to detail, a proactive work attitude, good judgement and the ability to work independently and as part of a team within the spirit of course goals and philosophies.
Student Leadership Certification or courses in the Student Leadership program (Student Success Office) are an asset.

Training, team-building, resiliency, adaptability, mentoring and other resources are provided all term and there is the opportunity for growth in many areas -- technical, personal and interpersonal --depending on the individual. Since the ISA job is not a permanent position, we strive to ensure that those employed as ISAs learn many skills transferable to any career they choose to pursue.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,Develop new features and polish existing features in a web application that is critical to UWaterloo's academic advisors and decision-makers.

column1: OAT (Online Academic Tools) is a suite of tools that includes student records for academic advisors, querying student data to assist university decision-makers, tools to send bulk mail to students (you've probably received some of it!), collect information from students via forms, and others.

OAT is built using a modern web framework and the super-cool Scala programming language.  We have many ideas for improving the experience of OAT's users and for extending its capabilities.  The successful candidate will be directly involved in analyzing, designing, developing, and testing those solutions.

It's a small development team.  Expect to work 1-1 with the lead developer with little to no down-time.  As a UWaterloo job, you can take a course, don't need to move, and can maintain friendships with folks on campus.","Develop Scala code:  analyze issues; design, implement, and test solutions.","Here's our wish list.  That said, we can do lots with someone who has only some of these skills.
* Scala programming experience.  If no experience with Scala, at least functional programming experience.
* Experience writing SQL queries.
* Experience writing code that runs on a browser (we use Scala on the browser as well as the server, transpiled to Javascript)
The usual soft skills:  good communication skills, attention to detail, organized, self-starter, trustworthy, etc.","Targeted Clusters

column1: Department: Dean of Science Office
Position: Outreach Assistant
Dates: January 4 to April 22, 2022
Hours: 8:30 a.m. - 4:30 p.m. but variable
**This is a Work Placement position.

The Faculty of Science Outreach team is looking for an organized, creative, and personable individual to develop and deliver education projects that support science-focused community outreach. This may include but is not restricted to: preparing materials for potential workshops to school classrooms with virtual delivery and/or video instruction or in-person delivery, through Let's Talk Science and Science Outreach; communicating with teachers and other partners to schedule outreach activities; assistance with event coordination. If possible, this role will be on-campus, although if necessary much work can be done remotely with intermittent access to campus to retrieve supplies. This is an opportunity for a Waterloo Science student who is passionate about science to inspire others to explore scientific innovation and discovery, while developing their own skills in communication, organisation, and education. Experience with Science or Engineering Outreach is an asset. Experience with Science or Engineering Outreach is an asset, as is a full Driver's license.","Job Responsibilities (may include all or some):
- Research, implement, and evaluate activities supporting community outreach
- Improve, develop and/or create activities and resources to support science learning
- Assist with museum collections cataloguing and maintenance, and exhibit development
- Develop and maintain relationships with external stakeholders including but not limited to schools, community organizations, teachers, alumni, donors, and students
- Provide support as a member of a team of professionals dedicated to furthering the initiatives of the Faculty of Science","Qualifications:
- Excellent oral and written communication skills are essential
- Enthusiastic, personable, and good with kids/teenagers
- Attention to fine detail and excellent organizational abilities
- Strong computer skills including Microsoft Office Suite, and experience with virtual communication platforms and/or video editing
- Must be a self-starter, be able to work both independently and as part of a team","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,This position is in the Department of Earth and Environmental Science at the University of Waterloo for a four-month work term, renewable for a second term contingent upon satisfactory performance, beginning January 2022. As part of Canada Excellence Research Chair program in ecohydrology, we are looking for interested Co-op students to join our research team as a research laboratory assistant to work in a research project with a group of researchers from different field of biogeochemistry, hydrology, and environmental chemistry and microbiology.

column1: Research in the ecohydrology program focuses on the fluxes and transformations of nutrients, greenhouse gases and heavy metals at critical interfaces separating groundwater from surface water bodies, including hyporheic zones, riparian soils, seepage areas and subterranean estuaries.","Assist researchers in performing a variety of technical duties in laboratory and field research projects.
See above.","A motivated innovator with creative energy and initiative
Interest in Environmental study, Hydrology, Ecology and Biogeochemistry
Experience with analytical chemistry and/or biochemistry techniques (e.g., wet chemical extractions of nutrients and metals, enzymatic bioassays, quantitative PCR, gel electrophoresis)
Experience with microscopy (e.g., light, fluorescence, scanning electron)
Experience with (and interest in, ideally) analytical chemistry and/or biochemistry method development and troubleshooting
Experience with QC/QA evaluation of data using formulas in Excel
Other Job Details
Work with a team-based atmosphere
35 hours work per week","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,Wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) has been recognized as a potential tool to monitor trends in community infection of COVID-19. Isolation of gene fragments of the viral RNA from the wastewater followed by quantification using RT-qPCR has been demonstrated as a sensitive method.  We are currently working with various waste water treatment plants (WWTPs) to collect influent and effluent and quantify for the presence of COVID-19.  The student will be preparing coolers and samples, driving to the WWTPs to collect samples, sample processing and extraction and analysis by qPCR.","* Sample collection at various waste water treatment plants

column4: * Preparation of sample bottles and coolers.
* Preparing reagents and tubes for extractions.
* Processing samples upon arrival at campus.
* Centrifugation of waste water samples.
* Extraction of RNA from waste water samples using a kit.
* Maintaining databases and data collection.
* Valid G drivers license is required and should be comfortable driving large trucks (F150).","* Meticulous note taking and attention to detail
* Communication.
* Time management.
* Flexibility to work odd hours as needed.
* Pipetting.
* qPCR knowledge is not required but is an asset.","Targeted Clusters

column1: ,University of Waterloo,Faculty of Science,1,Open for Applications,Waterloo,Intermediate, Senior",10,"

column8: ,4 month work term,The Groundwater Geochemistry and Remediation Research Group in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences at the University of Waterloo is currently seeking applicants for an undergraduate co-op student research assistant position. Depending on COVID-19 field and lab access restrictions, the student will be responsible for the general upkeep and daily maintenance of various experiments in a wet chemistry laboratory and may assist with sample collection and analysis. This role also has the potential to include work in our geochemistry labs on the University of Waterloo campus as well as participate in field work at remote sites in northern Ontario and elsewhere in Canada, contingent on the restrictions surrounding COVID-19.

column1: If COVID-19 related field and laboratory restrictions are reinstated the position will be primarily completed remotely and the student will mainly assist research group members with the development of figures and diagrams relating to groundwater geochemistry, contaminant fate and remediation.","Depending on COVID-19 field and lab access restrictions, the student will be responsible for the general upkeep and daily maintenance of various experiments in a wet chemistry laboratory and will assist with sample collection and analysis. In addition, the student may be required to participate in field work at remote sites in northern Ontario and elsewhere in Canada. Tasks will include field and laboratory collection of water and solid-phase samples, measurement of geochemical parameters and dissolved constituents (e.g., pH, Eh, alkalinity, ammonia, phosphate, sulfide), conducting microbial enumerations, and assisting with field-site instrumentation. The successful applicant is expected to work independently and as part of a team with technicians and graduate students. This position requires proper handling and use of toxic substances, concentrated inorganic acids, and compressed gases. Job-specific safety training will be provided for field and laboratory activities as needed.

If COVID-19 related field and laboratory restrictions are reinstated the position will be primarily completed remotely. The student will be responsible for communicating with researchers and working independently to create and edit scientific figures and diagrams from collected data, this may involve the use of software such as CorelDraw and Microsoft Excel.","Applicants should have:
Completed university-level introductory chemistry
Some experience using Microsoft Excel and CorelDraw.
Previous field and laboratory experience will be considered an asset.","Targeted Clusters

column11: Earth Sciences Museum Collections Research Assistant

column1: ,University of Waterloo,Faculty of Science,1,Open for Applications,Waterloo,Junior, Intermediate, Senior",26,"

column8: ,4 month work term,Job Background:

column1: The Earth Sciences Museum holds thousands of rocks, minerals, fossils, meteorites and artifacts in its collections. The collections while on display in public museum spaces are also hidden in storage and hidden during this time of COVID. Our goal is to create an online database so that the Museum can better connect with visitors outside of our physical space. To accomplish this task specimen information needs to be entered and collection specimens need to be accounted for in the database.
Job Description:

As the Earth Sciences Museum Collections Research Assistant your primary task will be to build our database by working intimately with the collection(s). It will be your job to ensure all museum specimens are accounted for in the database, their information is recorded, specimens are labelled properly, labels are accurate, and specimens are photographed (you will not need to photograph them).","Responsibilities:
Systematically determine which specimens are not in the database.
Identify and research specimens to ensure data accuracy.
Enter referenced specimen data in database.
Create labels and label specimens.
Work with curator and volunteer to ensure specimen information is accounted for and photographed.","Required Skills:
Loves rocks, minerals, and fossils
Organized and detail oriented
Careful and patient
Excellent hand/finger dexterity (for adhering small labels on delicate specimens)
Experienced with Microsoft Excel
Excellent knowledge of or interest in rocks, minerals, fossils, meteorites, Earth Sciences artifacts and earth history.
Other Job Details:
You will need to be available weekdays between 8:30 am and 4:30 pm or 9:30 am and 5:30 pm.
The person for the job does not need to possess all of these skills but having the majority of them would be helpful.
You will be working in the Earth Sciences Museum public spaces every day and will need to adhere to COVID regulations.
You will also need to adhere to museum collection standards by wearing gloves when handling any specimen, and by handling specimens with the utmost care and patience.","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Science Recruitment team is looking for a creative, outgoing individual to assist with activities and projects that support the recruitment of future students. column1: ,University of Waterloo,Finance,1,Open for Applications,Waterloo,Junior, Intermediate, Senior",3,"

column8: ,4 month work term,The Financial Reporting Associate is jointly accountable to the Associate Director, Management Reporting & Budgets and Associate Director, Financial Controls & Systems for the execution of activities relating to the development, testing, and documentation of management reports.

column1: The incumbent will participate in requirements gathering sessions and lead the design, testing, implementation, and ongoing enhancement/maintenance of reporting, primarily using Microsoft Power BI and leveraging the University's Azure Data Lake.
Nature and Scope

Contacts: The incumbent must possess superior interpersonal skills and conduct themselves in a professional manner at all times. Excellent written and verbal communication skills are essential. This position communicates internally with Finance team members as well as administrative staff, and others across the campus community.

Level of Responsibility: The position is responsible and accountable for the projects and other work that s/he leads. Expected to develop expertise in business intelligence and analytics specialization.

Decision-Making Authority: This position is expected to be self-directed and work independently with some guidance.  In complex or unusual situations, issues may need to be elevated to the Associate Director, Management Reporting & Budgets or the Associate Director, Financial Controls & Systems.
Physical and Sensory Demands: Minimal as the position works in a typical office environment.

Working Environment: The University operates in a decentralized environment in terms of decision-making and a centralized environment in terms of establishing standards, policies, procedures and financial systems. Due to the nature and the complexities of the University business activities, disagreements and contentious issues and situations may arise from time to time due to differing interpretations of policies and procedures. Diplomacy and tact are required in all situations.","Reporting Requirements Gathering
- Participate in consultations and requirements gathering sessions with stakeholders to understand requests for financial and finance-related management reporting
- Clarification, analysis, and requirements validation to ensure a fulsome understanding of reporting requests
Data Analysis and Reporting
- Development, testing, and maintenance of management reporting and financial dashboards based upon gathered requirements
- Providing quality data, analytical support and reports, in an efficient and easily understandable way to a wide variety of audiences and users
- Analysis of data using best practice methodologies and consistent definitions to support evidence-based decision making and to identify trends
- Understanding relevant tools, systems and practices in the Microsoft Power BI suite to recommend ongoing improvements in data analytics
- Review and recommend presentation, content and parameters of management reporting while considering data access control frameworks, sustainability, scalability and systems capabilities
- Maintains confidentiality of data, demonstrating discretion and respect while meeting the information needs of the institution and without violating confidences

- Where information of a personal nature is concerned that the Associate may be responsible for or have access to, strict confidentiality must always be maintained including determining what can and cannot be provided to various requestor groups or possibly how it must be presented
Report Documentation
- Develop documents, including process diagrams, to validate analysis and confirm stakeholder requirements
- Development of standardized data definitions and reporting methodologies that can be integrated into institutional data programs
Other
- Participate in other department projects and complete other assignments as required","Education
- Post-secondary education
Experience
- Experience with requirements gathering would be considered an asset
- Strong preference for experience in report-building design and documentation
- Experience with Microsoft Power BI suite is an asset
- Experience in an accounting/finance-related environment would be an asset, but is not required
Knowledge/Skills/Abilities
- Conceptual thinker with strategic planning skills and initiative
- Superior interpersonal, communication and listening skills
- Strong analytical, technical and problem-solving skills
- Exceptional attention to detail
- Time management skills
- High degree of discretion, judgement, sensitivity, tact and diplomacy
- Works independently and has a strong work ethic
- Demonstrated ability to prioritize and manage concurrent assignments accurately and efficiently","Targeted Clusters

column8: ,4 month work term,The Human Resources Department is responsible for assisting in the provision and maintenance of a positive working environment for all university employees, which will foster achievement of the University's primary goals of teaching and research, through excellent client service.  In addition, Human Resources supports the opportunity for employees to reach their potential and achieve excellence through the effective administration and interpretation of corporate policies and practices, applicable federal and provincial legislation as well as its involvement in the administration and delivery of programs for personal and professional growth.

column1: The department provides service to the campus community in the areas of pension and benefit administration, salary administration, recruitment, career counseling and training and development.  Human Resources bases its service on the principles of equity and confidentiality with an emphasis on excellence in both customer service and employee relations.

The Pension Assistant is responsible for providing support to the Pension team and works closely with the members of the Pension Team, and will interact with all areas within Human Resources, as well as active and retired plan members.","- Prepare pension calculations, letters, and statements for members, follow-up with members who have not returned completed forms
- Prepare pension payment directions and reconcile benefit payments to pension fund statements
- Respond to pension inquiries by email and telephone
